byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Steven Erlanger, Palko Karasz and Iliana Magra from London; Gaia Pianigiani from Rome; Adam Nossiter, Alissa Rubin and Benoît Morenne from Paris; Alison Smale and Melissa Eddy from Berlin; Michael Forsythe from Hong Kong; Jonathan Soble from Tokyo; Simon Romero from Rio de Janeiro; and Neil MacFarquhar and Lincoln Pigman from Moscow. Vanessa Piao and Charlotte Yang contributed research.

abstract: Global reaction to Orlando, Fla, nightclub massacre combines both empathy with struggle against terrorism and anti-gay hate crimes, and perplexity at persistence of lax gun regulations in America.
lead_paragraph: The Orlando massacre resonated across the world not as an American anomaly, but because it felt so universal.

headline.main: Globally, Orlando Attack Strikes Now-Familiar Fault Lines
headline.print_headline: In Now-Familiar Rituals, World Reacts to Massacre With Mourning and Outrage

snippet: The Orlando massacre resonated across the world not as an American anomaly, but because it felt so universal.
